descript.abstract: This data layer shows the street rights-of-way in Newton, Massachusetts. The features in this data layer come from the PARCELS data layer.
descript.purpose:
These data are intended for researchers, students, and policy makers for reference and mapping purposes, and may be used for basic applications such as viewing, querying, and map output production, or to provide a basemap to support graphical overlays and analysis with other spatial data.
More advanced user applications may focus on urban and regional planning, transportation analysis and planning, and other associated themes.
descript.supplinf: There are no arc or polygon attributes other than the standard ones created for an Arc/Info coverage. This data layer is updated by periodically repeating the process described in the Data Quality section of this record. Maintenance is only required when new streets are created or the layout of existing streets changes.

idinfo.accconst: Access is granted to licensee (Harvard University) only. Available only to Harvard University affiliates.
idinfo.useconst: For educational or non-commercial use only.
idinfo.datacred: GIS data supplied by City of Newton GIS.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows NT Version 4.0 (Build 1381) Service Pack 6; ESRI ArcCatalog 8.2.0.700

dataqual.logic: For layers containing line or polygon features, Newton's data layers are "topologically clean". This was verified with Arc/Info software version 7.x in 1998 and is an ongoing part of data maintenance for the relevant data layers.

horizpa.horizpar: No systematic and quantitative review of property boundary accuracy has ever been conducted. However, several qualitative observations based on experience using the data are possible. The street right-of-way lines overlay the orthophoto base map very well, falling on or close to the apparent back-of-sidewalk visible on the photos. When the right-of-way lines do not match the photo exactly measurements of the difference are typically +/- three feet. Since the photos absolute accuracy specification was +/- 2.5, this suggests that the right-of-way lines have a comparable accuracy in most cases. Comparing the right-of-way boundaries with the edge-of-pavement data layer reinforces this conclusion. The edge-of-pavement data layer was compiled from aerial photography for Boston Edison to an absolute accuracy specification of +/- 2.5 feet. Again, the right-of-way lines match up well in this comparison. Less is known about the accuracy of the internal property boundaries. Casual observations suggest they are sometimes as accurate as the right-of-way lines and sometimes much less. Some observations of boundary line discrepancies relative to property boundary lines such as fences and hedges visible on the orthophotos indicate that internal property boundaries may be off by at least +/- 5 feet.

srcinfo.srccontr: Attribute information for this STREETS RIGHTS-OF-WAY layer were derived from the PARCELS datalayer.

procstep.procdesc: The features in this data layer come from the parcel data layer. The right-of-way arcs were identified by selecting all arcs in the parcel data layer where the lpoly# or rpoly# item values = 1 (the "universe" polygon ID) and saving them to a separate file. In Arcedit, the saved arcs were then selected and the UNSPLIT NONE command was used to remove unnecessary ("pseudo") nodes. Finally, polygon topology was created and labels were added with, respectively, the Arc BUILD and CREATELABELS commands. This data layer has polygon topology. Orthophotographs were used to create planimetric base maps for the Parcels layer from which features for this layer were derived. The maps included topographic contours with a two-foot contour interval. The maps were adjusted to fit features such as the apparent back-of-sidewalk on the base map, and then property boundaries were traced onto the map. These property lines were then digitized using computer assisted drafting (CAD) software. In 1991 Applied Geographics, Inc. (Boston, MA) developed an Arc/Info version of its property parcels. This coverage contains boundary lines for the approximately 24,200 Assesor's property parcels. Sources for features derived from aerial photography, orthophotos, topographic contours, survey control monuments, and mapping water/sewer/drain infrastructure based on targets painted on the streets and conducted by the James W. Sewall Co. The aerial photographs were taken on April 15, 1994. The photographs were produced at a scale of 1" = 600' (1:7200) at an approximate altitude above datum of 3,600 feet. The information below is from the J. W. Sewall Co. Proposal Documents Scale of Photography: 1:7200 Forward Overlap: 60% average within 5 feet. Side Overlap: 30% average within 10 feet Tilt: Not to exceed 3 degrees - 4 degrees between flight lines Crab: Not to exceed 3 degrees relative to flight line Contact Prints: 9" x 9" received from company. Ground Control: Primary - 12 permanent control markers set - 36" concrete monuments. GPS network of 50 stations with three horizontal and nine vertical ties to grid. Network tied to MSPCS NAD83 datum and NGVD29 datum by occupying Mass. Highway Department control points. Block Adjustment Accuracy: Horizontal: second order class I; Vertical: third order Model: ALBANY-Lite Final Pixel Size: 12 inches Final Horizontal Accuracy: Approximately +/- 5 feet.
The original shape file was imported to an ArcSDE Layer.

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

enttyp.enttypd: ESRI Shapefile. Polygons represent block rights-of-way
